characters: MUSIC CUE CONTINUES OVER FOLLOWING SCENES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: BILLY MATTHEWS, 8, ravenously eating a plate of hashbrowns, runny fried eggs and syrupy waffles.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Doug?... We see DOUG MATTHEWS, 40's, sitting across the table, staring at his son, Billy. Doug is handsome in that honest, sincere way. A guy you would call to help you move a couch. He watches Billy scoop up his hashbrowns with a frosted pop-tart. Billy catches his Dad's look and grins with his mouth full. Doug smiles back, then looks down at his own plate. He has scrambled egg whites and sliced tomatoes. His smile fades away.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Doug? Doug snaps out of it and looks up at his wife, KELLY MATTHEWS. She's attractive, with a patient smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some stuff to do for the party tomorrow. Can you take Billy to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What "stuff"? This party isn't going to be fancy, is it? Just some friends and a wing platter from Costco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a our 10th anniversary, Doug. Its going to be a nice party with nice food and nice music. And wings have carbs, so you can't eat them anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll eat 'em. Doug gives Billy a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you won't. Because I'm going to scrape the batter off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to medical school. You think I don't know how carbs work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dentists go to medical school? Doug looks a little insulted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug, can you take Billy or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can take him. There aren't any emergencies at the office this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have emergencies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have emergencies. That's what my pager is for. one beep from that thing, and bam. I'm off. Like a cheetah. Billy, now pouring lucky charms into a bowl, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battery ith gone in that thing. You took them out for the TV clicker. Doug gives Billy a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did do that. I forgot about that. I need to get some batteries in there. Because dentists do have emergencies. We are doctors, you know? We take the same oath. The oath of saving lives. Doug goes to take some of Billy's discarded Lucky Charms. Billy swats his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh. Carbth. Doug nods, defeated, as Billy hops up and dumps the remaining lucky charms in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG drives a Volvo station wagon along the streets of Cincinnati. BILLY is next to him, in the passenger seat, looking bored. Doug notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I use to race a car like this. Put a hemi under the hood... Nobody saw me coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. It could really... smoke some ass. Billy raises his eyebrows, impressed. Doug smiles. This was a good time to break the "no saying ass" rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They called it the dragon wagon. You're lucky to be in here without a helmet, pal. We both are. Doug downshifts a gear, and the tame engine roars artificially. Billy is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awesome! Hey, can I jam the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heck yeah, you can jam the radio. Doug tussles Billy's hair and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Volvo pulls up to a red light. Radio Disney blares "MICKEY LOVES MAMBO" from the stereo. BILLY bobs his head along with the music. DOUG looks out the window and sees a mid-twenties guy in a Porsche, staring at him. Doug nods hello, then awkwardly faces forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 4.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON SPEAKERPHONE
dialogues.text: Bob?... BOB LEVENSTEIN, 40s, is working at his computer. Bob is good enough looking, but with a gawky wimpishness and burdened eyes. He tries to ignore the speakerphone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON SPEAKERPHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bob!? Bob cringes at the shrill, female voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, honey.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON SPEAKERPHONE
dialogues.text: You need to come tell Haley she can't go to a party tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into speaker phone) Well, I'm technically at the office right now, so... The door behind him flings open, and KAREN LEVENSTEIN, attractive and harsh-looking, steps in holding a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me!? You work in our guest bedroom, not an office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I was just trying to make this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I have to go to a job that actually makes us money, Bob. So, get out here and tell Haley she's not going anywhere! Bob nods obediently and hurries out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob enters the kitchen. His five year-old daughter, CLAIRE, wearing a dance leotard, walks up to him and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Daddy. Listen. (screams at the top of her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob winces, and looks around for his other daughter.

dialogues.speaker: SFX
dialogues.text: Bob reaches for it, but his other teenage daughter, HALEY, runs in, wearing a denim mini-skirt and Ugg boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!! Don't touch that! It's Julien! Haley snatches the phone away from Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I need to talk to you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Julien. Yeah, totally. I'll probably just drop by and chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's about the party, you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! I'm talking, here. God! Haley storms out of the room. Bob goes to say something, but CLAIRE enters and looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eeeeeeeiiiiiaaaaa!! Bob just stares at her, as Karen enters the Kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling above Claire) Did you talk to her? Tell me you talked to her. God! I have to do everything! Just get Claire to ballet. She's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I really have to finish my--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your little article for the "Web" magazine, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a shareholder meeting. And we agreed that my career would be the priority, and you would work out of the house. You might not like it, but my job is higher paying. And I don't see you complaining about that hundred dollar shirt you're wearing. Bob looks down at his too-hip dress shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bought this shirt for me. I was fine with my t-shirts--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't like the shirt now? Fine. Take it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it off! You don't want to wear nice things, don't. Off! Bob sighs and takes the shirt off. Karen snatches it from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take Claire to her ballet class. It's starts in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have to get another--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go! Five minutes! Karen pushes Bob out the door, with Claire skipping happily behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob sits in the car, SHIRTLESS, next to Claire. He looks over at her, and notices a pink hoodie in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to wear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For five dollars, I'm not. Bob sighs and reaches for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of kids in dance leotards are starting a class. Claire comes running into the group, as Bob enters behind her, wearing the pink hoodie. It's way too small, and doesn't quite cover his belly. He sits with the parents and nods awkwardly to them. It's embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the pristine living room of an expensive, architectural house.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody Stevens! We see WOODY STEVENS, 40s, handsome, but with shifty eyes and a Michael Keaton hairline, walk through the stylish house speaking into a cordless headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .No, you listen to me. You're not going to push me around. We agreed on a price, and that's the price I'll pay. If you don't like it, walk away... but you can kiss your business good bye, because that's what happens when you screw with Woody Stevens. You go down. Hard. As Woody talks, he passes by framed magazine covers of a beautiful model, (CLAUDIA) as well as some pictures of his wedding day with her, their exotic vacations, and one blownup glamour shot of Woody, shirtless, oiled and holding a greasy wrench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .No, money's not the problem (LAUGHS) Money's never a problem. You just need to honor the correct price. Got it? Woody gets his answer, and angrily throws the headset down on a stack of moving boxes. He marches to the front door and throws it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody yells out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .Then go home, Toby! You make me sick! ANGLE ON: The front yard. A ten-year-old boy is standing with a rake, surrounded by leaves. He clicks off his cellphone and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this many leaves for ten bucks! It'll take two hours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you should have thought of that before you put the "any yard for ten bucks" flyer on the telephone pole. You're done on this block, now. And that goes for your band fund-raisers, too. I'm not buying any candy bars no matter what parade you dorks have to get to! Woody slams the door closed. Toby kicks at a pile of leaves, then starts home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see an office crowded with disassembled Apple computers, motherboards, and abandoned monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley? ANGLE ON: DUDLEY FRANK (late 30s), an odd-looking, curly- haired guy with black plastic glasses that are slightly too big for his face. He stares at a computer in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hey, Mac. How's it go--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now nine o'clock am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mac. Open internet, okay? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Command unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac. Open. Internet. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now nine o'clock am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Mac. I'll show you. Dudley clicks a few keys and nods satisfactorily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Internet open. Dudley laughs good-naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, because I just opened it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I need to research alternative specs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Searching "alternative sex."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No! Dudley jumps forward and starts hitting the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two million websites found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to search that! I said specs... "all the data to be compiled."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Searching "sex all the day with child."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh, No!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 10. Dudley frantically starts ripping the power wires out of the computer. The monitor goes dark. Dudley touches it sadly, then looks over at a cat sitting on the edge of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like it's still just you and me, icat. Dudley reaches out to pet the cat. It hisses at him angrily, and he quickly pulls his hand back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, now in his lab coat, sits at his desk, playing with a model of a mouth. The phone rings and Doug answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, honey. INTERCUT WITH KELLY: On the phone at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, yeah. I've got a mouth right here in front of me. Doug takes a dental tool and hammers on the plastic mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they mind you being on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not attached to a head, really. More research. Doug hits the mouth too hard and all the teeth fall out. He fumbles to stop them from scattering everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, I just wanted to tell you I found a great rate for the Ritz-Carlton tomorrow night. I Thought it might be romantic. Mom can stay here with Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Do you think we really need to stay at a hotel? I mean, Billy has his own room. Why don't we just buy new sheets? Like, hotel-colored ones. It'll be like the Ritz, but we won't have to pay to make phone calls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I'm just saying-- Suddenly, the speaker comes on overhead.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Dr. Matthews? Patient emergency in room eight. Doug snaps to attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go! Emergency! Doug jumps out of his seat and scrambles over his desk and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug flies into an exam room, where a hygienist, DANA, is looking into a male patient's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Matthews. Finally. Take a look at this. Doug looks in the man's mouth and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acute molar abscess. That's going to need emergency surgery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. Thank God you got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's send him over to an Orthopedic surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Thanks, doctor. Doug nods. He looks around for something else to do, but there's nothing. He moves a dental tool away from the edge of a tray, smiles politely and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, looking depressed, pulls into the driveway. He looks over and sees BILLY and three of his friends shooting baskets. He smiles, gets out of the car and struts over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo! Matthews is open. Billy looks up and cringes a little bit, but passes the ball to DOUG. Doug dribbles it under his leg and charges the basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking it into the paint. Who's got the D? Whoop, too late, dudes! Booya! Doug jumps up to slam the ball, but only hammers it into the rim. The rim clangs loudly and the ball goes flying backwards. Billy's friends laugh a little. Doug notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's not really my shot. I usually hit from downtown, you know? Doug grabs the ball out of the bushes and dribbles back to the three point line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where the big games get won. Back here from the three-- Doug swivels, jumps up and releases the ball. It heads towards the basket, then falls down five feet before it. It looks more like a pass than a shot. Billy hangs his head, humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a pass, dudes! It wasn't. Doug nods with false confidence to the kids, stands there awkwardly for a moment, then quietly heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG enters and finds KELLY. She smiles and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, honey. Snack? Kelly hands Doug a sandwich bag of celery. He looks over to the table, where Kelly has laid out Ritz crackers covered in cheez whiz, for the kids. Doug puts the bag of celery down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay. I think I'm just going to go meet the guys for a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Lite beer, if you want to stick to that diet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Yes. Lite beer. No carbs. Just delicious beer... water. Doug smiles and heads upstairs. Kelly looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug enters his bedroom and shuts the door behind him. He sits down on the bed and lets out a long sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 14. After a moment, he gets up and walks over to the closet. He opens it and we see: A leather biker jacket, leather chaps, boots, gloves, a black "half-helmet," etc. For the first time, we see a genuine smile come over Doug's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage door on Doug's house rolls open like a theater curtain, and Doug, wearing the full leather biker getup, idles out of the garage on a gleaming, chromed-out Harley Davidson Fatboy. He looks around the neighborhood cockily, smiles, then kicks the bike into gear and rides into the street. The camera rotates around him and comes to rest on the back of his jacket, where we see a large patch that reads "Wild Hogs." The camera ZOOMS IN ON THIS, and it becomes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB creeps through the living room. From the kitchen, we can hear KAREN, HALEY and CLAIRE screaming things at him, about him, etc. He just tip-toes to the hall closet and opens the door. We don't see what's in it, but see Bob smile the same way Doug did, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB, in leather biker gear, rolls out of his garage on another shimmering Harley Davidson. He looks around through his mirrored aviator sunglasses like a complete bad ass. He looks down the street and spots DOUG, riding towards him. Bob rides down the driveway and joins alongside Doug. They nod silently to each other and tap fists like the toughest guys in the world. We see Bob is also wearing a "Wild Hogs" jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOODY walks through the courtyard, and into a pristine garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 15. He passes by a BMW 645, several stacks of labelled moving boxes, and finally a beautiful Harley Davidson Softail Anniversary Edition. A MINUTE LATER, Woody pulls onto the street on his Harley. DOUG and BOB turn the corner and nod to him. Woody nods back, revs his engine, and joins alongside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a garage crowded with disassembled Apple computers, printers, and a Harley Davidson Sportster. Out walks DUDLEY, who's biker outfit doesn't quite mesh with his thick-lensed eyeglasses. Dudley cockily pulls on a "Wild Hogs" jacket, kick starts the motorcycle, presses a button to open the garage door, and rides the motorcycle out. However, as he gets halfway out of the garage, the garage door catches on something, and snaps back down. It clotheslines Dudley off the bike, which rolls down the driveway and into some garbage cans. Dudley lays in the driveway, staring up at the sky with a pained look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB and WOODY ride towards Dudley's house, but find DUDLEY sitting in his driveway with his arms around his knees. He shrugs and motions to his motorcycle - Which he has stood back up, but has a bent wheel and smashed headlight. Doug and Bob take in the situation and then look at Woody. Woody rolls his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB and WOODY ride along. We see DUDLEY is riding bitch on Woody's bike, and Woody doesn't seem thrilled about it. The camera pans around and we see they are all wearing "Wild Hogs" jackets. And on this, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys pull up at a biker-theme bar with a motorcycle mounted above the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 16. Woody is obviously humiliated to have Dudley behind him, as they park the bikes among a crowd of other bikers. Dudley climbs off the back of Woody's bike and pats him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Woody. I feel really safe with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I noticed that. And if you ever lay your head on my back when you're riding bitch again, I'm going to throw you into traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was trying to keep my face out of the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt you smell my hair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys! Come on. Let's go get a brew. I'm buying. Doug heads into the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cool with the carbs? Doug pauses, without turning around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can have a light. Doug continues into the bar, but now with less swagger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are sitting at a worn table. The place is crowded with curiously gentle-looking bikers. Woody looks around the bar with a smirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I wish we could find a place that wasn't so freaking lame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? This place is cool. We're with other bikers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 17. Suddenly, a large, bald biker comes up and slams a beer down on their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild Hogs aren't welcome here! The guys all look at him for a beat - then the Bald guy cracks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Paul. PAUL laughs at his joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys... Woody, your tax return is almost done, but I want to talk to you next week about incorporating. A lot of my executive clients have been--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Paul. I'll talk to you about it on the trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll talk about in Daytona. (angrily, to group) What the hell are you staring at!? Paul glares at the other guys for a beat, then cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you guys. Paul exits. Woody shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place sucks. Why are we going to Daytona with these posers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's Bike Week. That's our annual trip, Woody. We're Wild Hogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not Wild Hogs. That's a patch your wife made and we all had to sew it on our jackets so she didn't feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! She took an embroidery class for those. What has your wife ever made us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn't... Don't tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a big secret, Bob. She's a swimsuit model. She's hot. I mean, so is my Kelly. She's very hot. Even after ten years. Not that I'm not still good looking... Doug looks at the guys. They don't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to say you're hot, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's gay, or because I'm not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no non-gay response to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were a girl, I'd be attracted to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point proven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Kelly must still think you're hot. Ten years, man. How's that feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Good, I guess. Is ten the silver anniversary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's the 25th. Ten is aluminum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aluminum? Like, siding? (considers, then) Yeah, that feels about right. Aluminum is sturdy, lightweight... recycled. Woody smiles and puts a map down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --And ready for the trip of a lifetime. The guys look at the map, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need a map for Daytona. We just follow the group. Woody takes a drink from his beer, then looks at the group with a mischievous fire behind his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if we don't go on the Daytona trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooo!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, listen to me. It's time for a change. Let's go on our own trip this year. Just us, like it was in college. Forget these guys. Forget Daytona beach. Bike Week is just corporate white guys playing dress up. This bar is, too. And we didn't get into this to play dress up - we got in this to live. "Be cool and Ride free." That's the Wild Hog creed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not. It's the slogan for the Downtown trolley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. But, it works as our creed, too. So let's live it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I boogie board in Daytona. Can't our creed be "Be cool and boogie board?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's dumb, Dudley. Let the big people talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what kind of trip are you suggesting? Another bike week somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's the best part. We don't do some planned out trip. We follow the open road. U.S. 50. The backbone of America. We take a week and go all the way to San Francisco. Think about it, guys. Camping out, stopping wherever we want, whenever we want... Just freedom. When was the last time we had that? The guys consider this, but look sceptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid to ask your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Daytona isn't the "backbone of America," but it is a tradition. We've been riding with this club for years. Do we really want to miss out on that? One of the bikers, KENT, approaches carrying a box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, dudes. Check these out. Kent holds up a sleeveless t-shirt with a big cartoon guy on a motorcycle - with the words "Born to Be Wild! Daytona ride, 2005." It's horrifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all going to wear these on the trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way everyone will know we're from the Cincinnati chapter. It'll also get you ten percent off at T.G.I.Fridays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool! Born to be wild! Dudley grabs a shirt and starts to pull it over the t- shirt he already has on. Woody gives a look to Bob and Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, We'll talk about it tomorrow. But we don't need some trip to go "live." We

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are living. Free and wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The anniversary party is in full swing. DOUG is watching

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: several guests dish steaming pasta and cream sauce out of a chaffing dish. He looks down at his plate of field greens and skinless chicken breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free and wild. Doug looks around the party. Several middle-aged couples are dancing on the living room floor. Others mingle, laughing... Everyone is having a great time, except Doug, who stands there, listless. Kelly walks up and kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sweetie. Having fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's getting pretty late, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should kill the music. Drop a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's eight O'Clock. It started at seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, that's late. We should just flicker the lights on and off. People will get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are having fun. Look at the Miltons. ANGLE ON: THE LIVING ROOM. A happy-looking couple, THE MILTONS, are dancing around to Prince's "1999." Doug  laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man. There should be laws against  that... Is Fred having a seizure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Fred's having a good time. With his  wife. Remember what that was like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we have fun all the time. But I'm not going to let myself look like that. He wears dress socks with shorts, too. I've seen it. Do you want me to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. Why do you?  Doug searches for a response, as ROGER, 70, Kelly's Dad,  clinks his wine glass at the front of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, everybody. I have a little  toast. For my daughter and her husband.  Roger winks at Doug and Kelly. Doug smiles weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto, to Kelly)  He's drunk. We should do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to start by saying how proud I am  of my son-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto, to Kelly)  --No, he's fine. Let him talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I have to make an admission. Ten years ago, when Doug and Kelly got married. I was worried. Doug was a little wild... The guests laugh. Doug gives an unsure chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, he had that old trans-am with the huge engine... Remember how he'd peel out of anywhere? Even the grocery parking lot after buying baby formula? The guests laugh again. Now Doug isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the way he'd just grab Kelly and run off to some crazy island to snorkel with something that thinks you're lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests continue to laugh. Kelly looks at Doug, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees this is landing on him. He's getting upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, not anymore. He's now become the son-in-law I would have always hoped for. Responsible, reliable, and a great husband to my daughter. So cheers to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. No cheers-- Because that wasn't an accurate toast. I'm still the same, shitty son-in-law I used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests laugh. They think he's joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Doug. You should be proud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've grown up! Cheers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests nod and clink their glasses. Doug shakes his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grown up? No, I haven't. I'm still

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: young. No cheers! Stop clinking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug, stop it. You're being rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell them I'm the same as I used to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: be, Kelly. Tell your Dad not to like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the same, Doug. The old Doug wouldn't have made fun of Fred Milton for dancing, because he would have been out there dancing himself. With me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying you have changed. And frankly, i don't like it. I like you the way you were. I liked it when you weren't afraid of looking stupid. I liked it when we laughed. I liked it when we danced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'll dance! It's just this music is lame. People like me need a fresh beat! Doug walks over to the stereo and changes the station. "Cand Sho " h y-50 Cent starts playing. Doug nods along with the beat, as the guests all now stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling over music) Awwww, yeah. This is the shit! It ain't 1980 anymore, man. Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take you to the... Andy shop-- Doug tries to confidently sing along, but struggles  awkwardly, as he's obviously never heard the song before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urging, to Doug)  Honey, stop it. You're being an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!? I thought this was what you  wanted? I'm dancing! Doug starts grinding and shimmying to the beat. Kelly  grits her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, baby! Just because we're  married ten years doesn't mea n we're old  people. Let's dance! It fee ls goooood!  Doug makes another spastic dance move, then suddenly  grimaces and grabs his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, that feels bad--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug? What's wrong? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm just-- Ow: That's-- Yeah, I should go to the hospital-- Doug staggers across the carpet as people run to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug is in a bed, with Kelly next to him. A DOCTOR enters with a chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Matthews--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Matthews, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Great. Then, I can say this a lot easier. You had a hypertensive myocardial seizure. Doug nods confidently, then, after a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a dentist, actually... I have no idea what you just said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry. It looks like you had a stress-induced panic attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stress-induced? I'm not stressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's probably been pretty buried. I actually see it a lot with middle-aged men. Work, family, it can take a toll on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not middle-aged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I see that a lot, too. Anyway. We should have you out of here soon. The doctor smiles and exits the room. Kelly looks at Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am middle aged, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only mathematically. Doug takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug, Let me ask you a question. When was the last time you sang a Bon Jovi song?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to sing Bon Jovi songs at the top of your lungs. Like you didn't care who heard you, or how dopey it sounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then one day, you just stopped. That's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: how it's been with everything. Romance, sense of humor, the way you used to give me that cocky little wink when you took

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: off your shirt... It's all faded away,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: leaving just a shell of what you used to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: be. Why? Why no more Bon Jovi songs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. There's just a lot weighing me down these days, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what? You have a great career, a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: perfect family. Money is fine. The only

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: thing that could be weighing you down is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: me. Is it me? Are you tired of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! of course, not. I could never be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug stops himself, as it dawns on him. You can see the horror of realization creep across his face. He looks at Kelly, wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. I'm weighing me down. I'm not a guy I'd hang out with anymore, I'm... Me. What's cool about me? I don't even eat carbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then eat them. I'd rather have you sing  than have a thirty-four waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still have a thirty--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't, Doug. I buy your pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. We've been married ten years. And personally, I'd like to be married fifty more, but if you stay like this... Then... I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are going to be married fifty more years, Kelly. I'm going to find old Doug. I just have to figure out where to look. Kelly takes a breath, and pulls out a map. She hands it  to Doug, who looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody's map?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took it away from him at the party. He  wouldn't stop waving it at Bob and  Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you agreed it was a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be. But I'm desperate, Doug. I want us to be happy again. So go on it. It's my anniversary present to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? (considers, then) I only got you an ankle bracelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I want is old Doug back. Please. This marriage can't survive without him.  Doug takes this in, and smiles at her. She's a good wife, and he knows it. Suddenly, BOB enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug! Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm okay. Just stress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man. Thank god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Karen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she's waiting in the parking-- SFX: A loud honk from the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's her. Bob looks out the window nervously. Kelly looks at Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all need this trip. Doug gives her a knowing nod, then turns to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob. Let's forget about Daytona Bike week. Let's ride across U.S. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Are you sure? I mean, We'll be leaving behind everything we're used to. SFX: The horn honks again from outside.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: (yelling from parking lot) Bob!? You said two minutes! I'm not circling!! Bob cringes. Doug shares a look with Kelly, then to Bob:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think that might be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG is riding his Harley, which is loaded with gear (sleeping bag, spare gas tank, saddle bags). He approaches a freeway entrance ramp, where WOODY and DUDLEY and BOB are waiting on their bikes, next to an entrance ramp sign that reads: U.S. Highway 50. The guys all tap fists, then notice Dudley is grinning ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a tat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tattoo? You got a tattoo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a biker, dude! I got a tat! Dudley yanks his jacket down to his elbows and we see he is wearing a sleeveless shirt underneath. On his bicep is a tattoo of the Macintosh Apple. The guys nod, trying to look impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. That's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trademarked, I know. But what are they going to do? It's in my skin, bitch! Dudley laughs and pulls on his jacket, as Woody ties a bandana skull-cap on his head. The guys look at Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not wearing a helmet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nape. I don't want anything between me and the road, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will if your head falls on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 30. Woody shrugs and starts his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, the only rule on this trip is to have no plan. We're riding to San Francisco, and nothing else is planned. Just riding free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if we're going to make it in five days, we'll should probably get to Illinois by tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the way I mapped it out - we should be a hundred miles past St. Louis by sundown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No. No plan. It's the open road. Who knows where we'll be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. I have this little GPS system. Doug shows them a handheld GPS system. Woody grabs it and throws it into a storm drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! What the hell, man? That was expensive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it for the good of the trip, Doug. You don't need GPS to discover America. We just need the wind, our bikes, and freedom. And if we have an emergency, I always have a cell phone-- Woody takes out a cellphone. Doug grabs it and throws it in the storm drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah! How's that feel? Woody gives Doug a long look, then slowly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It felt good. It felt damn good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cell phones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, Doug. Wild Hogs! Bob takes his cellphone and throws it in the storm drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just did that so Karen wouldn't call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Bob starts his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we're not even going to talk about this? I mean, shouldn't we at least--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeeeeaaah! Freedom!! Dudley throws his cellphone, but instead of going into the storm drain, it goes flying into traffic and smashes against an oncoming pickup truck. We hear the truck screech to a stop after it passes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's ride! The guys all hastily start their bikes and take off up the freeway ramp. We hear the truck driver screaming profanities as they guiltily ride away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CUE: BLUE OYSTER CULT's "(DON'T FEAR) THE REAPER." The four guys ride along the highway, through the hills of Indiana, smiling and nodding to each other. It's the Easy Rider moment. The camera ROTATES AROUND and PULLS OVERHEAD. It's beautiful country and the guys are in heaven. Dudley wears a clunky helmet from the eighties, as well as World War II motorcycle goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 32. A family in a station wagon pulls up to next to them. Two kids press their faces against the windows, looking at the bikers in awe. Bob looks over at the kids in his mirrored sunglasses and gives them a badass nod. The kids are amazed. Bob looks to Doug. Doug grins. They love this. Bob gives a signal to the other guys and guns his engine. The others nod, gun their engines and speed away from the station wagon. The kids watch with their mouths open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are cruising along as before, but now we see the sky has gotten very cloudy and overcast.

dialogues.speaker: SFX
dialogues.text: The guys look up at the sky apprehensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's now pouring rain. The guys ride along in misery, getting soaked. After a moment, the station wagon from before pulls back up to them. The kids are still pressed against the window, staring at the drenched bikers. Bob looks over and tries to give them another cocky nod - but now it's just embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has gone down, and the guys have found a deserted area off the highway to set up camp. DOUG, WOODY and BOB lounge by a fire - with a tent set up behind them. Doug is roasting marshmallows and Bob is straining to blow up an air mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you just bring a sleeping bag like us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is more comfortable. (blows a breath into it) I wish Karen would have let me buy the foot pump, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 33. Bob continues to inflate the mattress, as Dudley approaches with a knotted plastic grocery bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is poop. Don't eat it. Dudley sets the bag aside and has a seat by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley? You're supposed to bury that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Go bury it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in a plastic bag. I can't put that in the earth. I'll find a trash bin tomorrow. The guys shake their heads and look back into the fire. After a moment, Doug smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really nice, you know? Chilling by the fire with your best friends. Just relaxing, and enjoying--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Dudley, you have to get rid of that bag or I'm going to vomit in your lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --each other's company... Dudley grabs the bag and heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll just hang it on a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells after him) Don't hang it on a tree!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup... These are the times we'll remember. After a minute, Doug turns to Woody and Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, when was the last time you guys heard me sing Bon Jovi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man. Thank God that stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been awhile. You're not as obnoxious as you used to be. You used to eat a lot more buffalo wings, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. Turns out there's carbs in the batter. Hey, you know what? Maybe carbs are what I need to get old Doug back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Doug? You've lost your Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I think I've lost me. It's this thing Kelly said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what it is? I think I'm tame. I'm like a lion that used to be wild, but now I'm in some Disney park where tourists come by and take pictures of me like I'm a lion, but after they leave, I go into my kennel and eat antelope nuggets or something. Ones without carbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're talking about. I lost old Bob, too. I think my wife and daughters killed him. I'm surrounded by women every minute of my life. And it's made me, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wimp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No. I was going to say miserable. You think I'm a wimp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just thought that was what you were... I thought you wanted us to guess, and I didn't have a guess, so I said "wimp." Knowing it was wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a wimp, Bob. I'll say it. You're afraid of girls. It's embarrassing. Dudley comes up and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid of girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid to talk to one. Bob is afraid they'll kill him in his sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Now I really don't want to talk to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's not always so bad. Like, when Karen sleeps, she still crawls over and pushes up against me. Just snuggles right up like she needs me. I like that. I like that a lot. (then, sobering) Then the sun comes up and turns her into a raging she-demon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess life just isn't as simple as it was when we were in college. Well, except for you, Woody. You're still living the fairy tale. Swimsuit model wife. Big job at an investment firm. You've got the good life. Woody doesn't respond. He just stares vacantly into the fire for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... The good life. I'm a lucky man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life blows. I don't have a family. Or a wife. I have a cat that doesn't like me. She wouldn't even stick around if she knew how to use a can opener. The guys all look at Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dudley. You've got us, buddy. And you're going to get a woman, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you we were going to hit some strip clubs when we get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, I don't like those places--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley-- Please. I'm trying to help you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I just don't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Strippers are nice to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Sorry. We'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just... trying to be a good friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a surprise. Doug pulls a flaming marshmallow out of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, who wants their marshmallow well-done? The guys just look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I left that one on too long. Doug flips the stick and the marshmallow goes flying behind him. The guys don't notice - but we see the marshmallow land on the tent and continue to burn. Bob continues to huff on the air mattress. He stops and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of breath) I think I'm half way there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In just one hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want us to spread out a sleeping bag? We have three in the-- Doug turns around and sees a foot-wide flame now burning on the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! The tent-- Doug and the guys jump up and hurry over to the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley, get the water jug off my bike! Dudley hurries over to Doug's bike as Doug and Bob try to smother the flame with sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should be okay. It's fire retardant. The guys try and extinguish the flame as Dudley comes running with a jug. He quickly takes off the cap. Doug notices him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley, no! That'sВ— It's too late. Dudley is already throwing it on the fire. The liquid hits the tent and it explodes into flames. The guys shield themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gas! That's the spare gas tank, Dudley! Dudley doesn't know what to say. The fire quickly disentergrates the tent. Doug, Bob and Woody just watch, knowing there's nothing they can do. After a moment, DUDLEY runs back up with the correct water jug and empties it on what is now a flaming pile of ash. It does nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need more water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was all of it, Dudley. That was all the water we had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Dudley takes this in for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anybody else thirsty? The guys just look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB, DOUG, WOODY and DUDLEY are all sleeping on Bob's air mattress, like four sardines. Doug opens his eyes to see a large figure standing at the foot of the air mattress. It's a stern-looking highway patrolman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, just on a road trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Just making sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks pretty comfortable, actually. We see the highway patrolman has started rubbing his thigh. Doug quickly jumps up, waking the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well... Thanks for stopping. Have a nice day, officer. The highway patrolman laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five's a crowd. Doug is mortified. The officer looks them over for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY PATROLMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You guys are lucky to have each other. (looks at them hungrily) Damn lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I always say. Dudley gets up and puts his arm around Doug. We see he's wearing a saggy pair of briefs and nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Have a good one. The patrolman walks off. Dudley looks at Doug and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please put your pants on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys cruise through the rolling prairies of Missouri. It's another beautiful day. They ride in formation, until Woody's bandana doo-rag blows off. Woody goes back to get it. The other guys stop and wait for him to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are still riding - but now the heat of the Missouri plains is taking it's toll. They look boiling, and have sweated through their clothes. Bob takes a drink of water from a bottle of water, then pours the water over his head. He breathes a sigh of relief, until he hears an angry yell behind him. He looks back and sees Woody is now drenched from the water. Bob smiles sheepishly as Woody burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys ride through the forested Ozark uplands, looking even hotter than before. Doug spots a waterfall pouring into a crystal clear spring, and points to it. The guys nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, WOODY, and DUDLEY wade into the spring water in their boxers. You can see on their faces that it's like dipping into heaven. After a moment, BOB walks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for waiting for me, jerks. The guys look up to see that Bob is naked. He smiles and cannonballs into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whhheew: Yeah! That's c-c-cold: He sees DOUG, WOODY and DUDLEY are just staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you naked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're swimming. You guys kept on your skivies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skivies? What are you, a Newsie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kept mine on because I didn't want everyone to see my crank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That, and being naked with a bunch of guys is gay. What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. We took showers and stuff together in college. I thought this was kind of... you know, the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I get that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, we would have been naked in college. Why are we... Oh, man. It's true. We are tamed. We're old guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're not. Don't say that. Doug wiggles his boxers off and holds them in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will find old Doug! Doug smiles and throws his shorts on the shore. Dudley smiles, takes off his briefs and holds them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will... Do what Doug does! Dudley throws the briefs to shore. They all look at Woody. He rolls his eyes and takes off his boxers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be naked with my gay friends, and if they look at my jock, I will kill them. Woody throws the boxers to shore. The guys all look at each other and smile. It's a nice moment. Until a family approaches. Doug looks at the other guys, wide-eyed, as a family with three young kids walks up with a picnic basket. The young kids run and jump into the water. The Dad of the family laughs and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you guys don't mind a little company. The mini-van was getting a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dad stops talking as he sees into the water... He realizes, then looks at his kids, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Well, we're just taking a dip. I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a shallower spring up the path. The kids might like that even more... The Mom lays down a blanket and turns to the guys. The Dad is still staring, not sure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. These little squirts like to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mom sees a glimmer of something through the water, and realizes. She suddenly looks very uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janey, Kyle, Holland. Out of the water. We're going to find a new spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mama. This place has little rocks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of the damn water! Now! The kids climb out of the water and the parents hurry off with them down the path. After a moment of awkward silence, Doug looks at the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think? They're gone, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we could stay another few--

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Whhheeeeew! The guys look to the other side of the spring to see the HIGHWAY PATROLMAN cannonball naked into the spring. They stare, horrified, as he pops up and smiles at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw you're bikes out there. You guys ever chicken fight? The guys look at each other for a moment, then;

dialogues.speaker: DOUG/BOB/WOODY/DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Ahhhh! / Oh, god! / Run! They frantically sprint out of the water, grab their clothes and hurry away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are back on their bikes, cruising along the wheat fields of Kansas. They're looking tired once again, but suddenly Doug smiles... On the horizon, a bar comes into view. Out front are several rows of Harley Davidsons. Doug points it out to the guys and they all smile. It's like an oasis. The pull into the parking lot and climb off their bikes. Bob immediately falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit! Leg's asleep. The guys go to help Bob up, as Dudley gets off his bike and falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys have to shift every once in awhile. Blood has to circulate. A MOMENT LATER. Dudley and Bob are up and wiggling their sleeping limbs, as Woody looks up at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this is the best part of any road trip. Seeing our brothers on wheels. Look at this place. America! The guys look at it and nod. It is a cool looking shack of a bar. Doug admires the row of motorcycles out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at these bikes. They're all classics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man. Check it out. A 1951 Panhead. You know how rare this thing is? The guys all crowd around the bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but why didn't he customize it? You have a 51 panhead and you don't chrome out the exhaust? Or airbrush an eagle on the gas tank? What a waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably no good custom stores out here in hick-land. We'll leave 'em a catalog. The guys push open the door and step into the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar is full of bikers, but not the kind we saw before. These guys are greasy, tattooed and menacing. We see their jackets say "Hells Angels." The bikers turn and stare at WOODY, DOUG, BOB and DUDLEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hells Angels, huh? You guys are legends. I'm surprised we've never seen you in Daytona. The bikers kind of chuckle to themselves. The leader of the gang, JACK, steps forward. He's in his late 40's - and looks like he could break you into bite size pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, how do we keep missing that? The bikers all laugh. Doug and the guys join in, though they don't quite get what's so funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you re "Wild Hogs," huh? That's your gang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not a gang. Just friends. Friends that ride... you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's like a little hobby for you guys? How sweet. Doug smiles, but is now sensing the hostility. He looks back for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just a little hobby for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all successful professionals in real life. But on Tuesday and Sunday afternoons... We're bikers! Dudley spins around and shows them the back of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. That's great. Can I try that on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yeah, brother. Dudley whips his jacket off and hands it to Jack, who pulls it on his massive frame. He shows it to the gang, who laugh again. Dudley does, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who's '51 panhead is that? Sweet ride. Woody has a catalog so you can make it cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't. Doug does. I think it's great the way it is. Doug glares at Woody incredulously. Woody shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you like my '51, we should trade... "brother."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish! I just have a Sportster. It's worth, like, half of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Sportster!? That's what I grew up on. I've been wanting another Sportster. It's a deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously? You're serious!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley, maybe you should--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug, don't worry. Yeah, I'll have a cooler bike than you, but that doesn't mean I'll get all cocky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I don't care what you say! I ride a panhead now! I'm better than you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Dud. Let's go see how you look on it. Jack smiles and leads Dudley outside. Doug, Bob and Woody share an uncertain look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody else got that "pre-rape" feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is standing out front. Dudley starts to get on the classic motorcycle. Jack stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no. That's Oilcan's ride. My ' 51 panhead is right over there. Jack points to a pile of abandoned rusty motorcycles. Among it is the junked carcass of a '51 panhead next to an old, rusty sidecar. Dudley looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That? That's a piece of junk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Your piece of junk. Woody, Doug and Bob look at each other. This isn't good. Doug tries to laugh it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, guys. We get the joke... Good one. Anyway, we actually should get moving along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's no joke. You want to know the joke? Suburban assholes that buy leather outfits and think they're bikers. And it's a joke I'm damn sick of. So I'm keeping your friend's bike, I'm keeping this jacket, and you guys are going to turn the hell around and go back to wherever you came from, because the next hundred miles of this highway belongs to the Hells Angels. The color drains from the Wild Hog's faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like an adopt a highway thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a "Go home or we're going to split your skulls open" thing. Bob makes an audible whimper. Doug elbows him, and tries to look brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. We respect that this is your turf, and we're sorry for bothering you. But we can't head back without my friend's bike. So clearly we're going to have to work something out here. Jack looks back at the Hells Angels and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. We're going to have to work something out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see DOUG, BOB and WOODY riding away from the bar, looking very glum. The camera PULLS OUT to reveal the rusty sidecar is now attached to Woody's bike. DUDLEY sits in it looking miserable and cold (having lost his jacket and now in his sleeveless shirt). The guys get a good distance away from the bar and Woody waves for them to stop. They do and Woody looks back to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Let's just give them a few minutes to get back inside - then shoot right past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trip's over, Woody. Let's just head back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to turn back after all these miles? Just because some fat bully's pushed us around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. Woody shakes his head and looks at Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go wherever you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. See? Dudley's got some balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my sidecar's just attached to your bike. I'd prefer to turn back, but I could only roll so far...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you guys. What a bunch of pussies. The whole point of this trip is to live, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the point, Woody. Our lives aren't on this highway. They're back home. We have families, jobs, wives... or cats... We're not going to piss off a biker gang. We're going back. Woody takes this in, gritting his teeth in disappointment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Woody. You don't want to take this risk. You have Claudia, and your job... You have a great life back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 49. Woody looks up at him. Something about this has sparked something in Woody's eyes, but he covers it up with a calm smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, I do. But maybe I should talk to those guys one more time. I mean, I'm an executive at an Investment firm. I've made a career out of convincing people and these are just people. You guys wait here. Woody starts up his bike. Doug and Bob look at each other and shrug. Dudley hurries out of the sidecar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait here, too. You'll get better gas mileage. Dudley gets out and falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leg's asleep. Woody shakes his head and starts back to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody rides up to the bar, and looks back to make sure he's out of Doug, Bob and Dudley's sight. He sees that he is, and kneels next to the line of Hells Angels motorcycles. He takes out an army knife, and slices through one of the motorcycle's gas line. Gas starts leaking out onto the ground and Woody nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come after us now, assholes. Woody goes along to each bike, smiling with a weird recklessness as he slices through each gas line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOODY pulls up on his bike, where DOUG, BOB and DUDLEY are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're cool with it. We can press on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. I tried to be polite. I tried to reason. I told them Dudley was dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, technically we're all dying, Dudley. Just very slowly. Dudley looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm slowly dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, none of that worked. So I laid it out for them. I said, "Hey, go ahead and assault us. Because we might be not be real bikers, but we know real lawyers. And the moment you touch us is the moment you get your ass sued. Because this is the real world - with real laws, and real consequences." And they backed down. The guys are impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really said that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. And I think they'll give us Dudley's bike on the way back, so let's go. Quick. Before they change their mind. Woody quickly starts his bike and rides on. The guys shrug, impressed, and follow him. After a moment, we see them all speed by the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is playing darts with the other bikers. He goes to throw a dart and hears engines roar past the bar outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 51. He quickly turns, which makes the dart he was throwing fly off target and stick into the shoulder of one of the bikers, (OILCAN).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Shit, man! Jack listens as the engines pass the bar and fade away. Jack shakes his head, enraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saddle up, boys. Somebody doesn't listen. The guys nod and head outside. Oilcan pulls the dart out of his shoulder, and stops by Jack on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try and watch the throws, okay Jack? Jack glares at oilcan for a beat, then jabs a dart into his peck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Owww! Jesus! (off Jack's icy glare) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hells Angels roar away from the bar on their motorcycles. They get to the end of the driveway, and the bikes sputter and choke to a stop. ANGLE ON: JACK. He's on his hog, with a cigarette dangling out of his mouth. He looks down in confusion at the suddenly stalled bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the f-- (sees cut gas line) You've gotta be kidding me. Suddenly, the cigarette falls out of Jacks mouth, and onto the ground. A puddle of gas from the sliced line catches on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shit. The flames quickly follow the line of leaked gas like a fuse, back towards the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 52. Almost as quickly as the bikers can turn to look, the flame has reached the parking area and ignited all the puddles of gas. They all watch in horror as the fire ravenously engulfs the old wooden porch of the bar, then the roof ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys happily cruise along the highway. We see WOODY look in his side-view mirror and notice a large, black plume of smoke back in the distance. A look of worry creeps over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys pull up to a small motel, as the sun sets behind the wheat fields of Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're not stopping here. Riding at night is half the fun. Let's just keep--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I can't feel my nuts, Woody. And Kelly still wants another kid. DOUG, BOB and DUDLEY head inside the motel office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after Doug) So, adopt a kid. You already have two white ones, anyway. The guys ignore him. Woody looks back down the highway uneasily, then heads inside the motel office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK, and the other bikers stand by the smoldering pile of wood that was once their bar. OILCAN approaches Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got my old lady bringing some gas. We can get moving by nightfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. Those guys are long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not stupid enough to stop until they're five hundred miles from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB and DUDLEY are in their motel room. WOODY stands at the window, nervously looking outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just think it's just stupid to stop this soon, you know?... We can keep riding under the stars. All night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody, your headlight doesn't even work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I won't ride without light? I can feel the road. Let's go. I'll even race somebody. Who's racing me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you inhale exhaust fumes? Because something is happening to your brain. I think it might be retardation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to ride. Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever, Corky. Doug shrugs Woody off and dials his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, honey. It's me. Woody glares at Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're calling Kelly? You're not aloud to call wives on a road trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can call my wife whenever I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Woody. Good guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 54.
