dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm having a great time. No old Doug, yet, but I haven't gotten sun- burned... Woody looks at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You agree with me, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I actually agree with you on this one. Let's not call wives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Bob agreed with him. Good guess again. Man, I really miss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? I have to leave. Let me know when lame hour is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody, you can call Claudia when I'm done, if you want. You can use my cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not calling Claudia. I mean, yes I want to, but I won't. Because I'm on a road trip with my pals. And cell phones aren't even allowed! Woody storms out. Doug hears something on the phone, and lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Billy! How's it-- (then, into phone) Where'd he go?... Oh. He thought you were ordering pizza. Uh huh. Well, tell him I said hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB, WOODY and DUDLEY ride along the highway, as the sun burns the morning fog off of the wheat fields. Doug looks over to Woody and yells above the motorcycle engines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you made us leave so early. You really wanted to see the sun rise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man. It warms my heart, with it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentle... rays. Doug gives him a curious look, as they pass a sign that says "Lucas, Kansas. Population: 436"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling over engines) Hey! Let's stop for breakfast, I'm starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!? No! We're not hungry yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just said I was--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not! Fatty! Bob looks hurt. Doug gives Woody a stern look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Woody. It looks like a neat town. And Dudley's got another bag of poop to throw away. Dudley nods. Woody grits his teeth as they enter the town. It's a quiet, one stop-light town - with an old fashioned main street and town square. We see a banner over the street advertising a block party that night. It's a postcard version of small town America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner, BUD, is pressed up against the glass - watching the motorcycles come down Main street. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't tell me they're here again already. I just got the window replaced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 56. Bud walks back to the bar, past his daughter (and diner waitress) MAGGIE, 28, pretty in that cute, small town way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stay calm, Dad. At least it's not all of them, this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys pull up to the diner and we see the local pedestrians hustle away. The street is soon deserted, but the guys don't notice. They go to park their bikes, but there's not enough space. There's a police car in the parking spot next to them, and the town sheriff, CHARLEY, comes running towards it from across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll move it! Hold on, I'll move it! Charley jumps into the car and backs it out of its spot. The guys look at each other, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Lucas is a polite town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how these little towns are. It's unspoiled America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shithole. Let's keep moving. The guys ignore Woody and enter the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we'll get it to go, then. We can ride and eat if it's wrapped in a tortilla. Woody gets no response. He looks back down the road, uneasily, then follows the guys in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB, DOUG, WOODY and DUDLEY enter, with their motorcycle boots thunking on the wood floor, announcing to the entire diner that there are bikers there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 57 Everyone freezes and the place goes silent. The only sound is a single fork dropping onto a plate. BUD is pulsing with anger, but he swallows it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentleman. How nice of you to join us this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: well, how could we pass through this town without stopping? Everything looks so perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll change that, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? MAGGIE runs up and guides her Dad away from the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of them, Daddy. (to guys, extra polite) Good morning. Maggie smiles. She has a radiant sweetness, even though she's scared to death. DUDLEY stares at her, captivated. He's in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where would you gentleman like to sit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there any booths open? All the people quickly jump out of their booths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Everyone is so nice, here. The guys sit in one of the booths. Dudley hangs back, and struggles to talk to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... So? Dudley tries to think of something else to say, but can't. He nods awkwardly, then heads over to the booth. He sits down with the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like the waitress, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to say something funny to her, but I could only think of black jokes. Maggie, still very skittish, approaches the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what would you gentleman like today? Doug looks to the next table, where a man is enjoying french toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm. I'll have what he's having. Maggie nods obediently and takes the man's plate. She slides it in front of Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, uh... I'll take a new one. He can keep his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. Maggie quickly puts it back on the man's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's okay. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just don't let it happen again! Bob hammers his fist on the table and laughs at his joke, but Maggie starts to cry. The guys suddenly look confused as she runs to the kitchen in tears. Bob looks back to the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. That wasn't funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to be funny without being racist. Doug is looking at the town's local paper, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys. This block party tonight looks cool. Music, grilled corn, dollar beers, funnel cakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funnel cakes!? Let's stay here tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no. We have a schedule. San Francisco is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What schedule? You said we're taking this trip to live. Let's stick around and live a little. Have some small town fun! Woody goes to protest again, but Dudley stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's party all night in Lucas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (O.C. From kitchen area) God Dammit! What'd we do to deserve this!? We ANGLE TO SEE: MAGGIE rush over to calm BUD down. Bud calms down, then hears another motorcycle engine roaring down the street. He looks out the window and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not another one of these assholes. A moment later, MURDOCK, a fat, grungy Hells Angel, enters the diner with a cocky swagger and has a seat at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a beer, old man. And if it's not good, I'm going to smash it across your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 60. ANGLE ON: The WILD HOGS, watching from the table behind Murdock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto, to the guys) Not another one of these assholes. Murdock hears this and whips around to see the Wild Hogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I was actually referring to some guys we met at a bar about two hundred miles east of here. You're probably not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my gang. I'm on my way there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly, to Doug) so he is one of those assholes, Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Murdock puts his beer down, and stares angrily at Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who the hell are you freaks? Doug starts to answer, but Woody, looking nervous, cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Oh, we're just a group of friends. No big deal. Your guys gave us permission to pass by, so it's all good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hells Angel's don't give permission. Especially to a bunch of ball-less wimps like you. Bob hammers the table and stands up - his face red with long-suppressed rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a wimp, pal'. I'm a man! You got that? Huh? You got that!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 61. The guys look at Bob, wide-eyed. woody looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, let's not get carried away--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you know what? This guy needs a talking to just like his friends did, Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Bob. I don't think--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me do this, Woody! You stood up to them last time, and I just sat there like I always do... Well, not this time! (turns to Murdock) Listen, you piece of shit. You think you can just walk around and bully perfectly nice people? You think that's how it works? Well, guess what? This is the real world. With real laws and real consequences. You hear me!? Bob swats Murdock's beer out of his hand. It spills all over him. Murdock is too filled with rage to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get out of here! And if that gang of inbred assholes needs things explained to them again, tell 'em the Wild Hogs will be right here in Lucas tonight. Woody puts his face into his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get. Murdock just stares daggers at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get! Bob kicks the stool out from under Murdock. He almost falls, but catches himself on a stool. He glares at the guys, but he's outnumbered. He grits his teeth and storms out the door. Woody winces to himself as he watches Murdock go. This isn't good. After a moment, BUD comes running out from behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... You guys aren't Hells Angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Us? Oh, no. We're from Cincinnati. Bud calls out to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley!? They ain't the bad ones! CHARLEY, the sheriff from before, stands up from behind a countertop in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys aren't Hells Angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We're Wild Hogs. That's our gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And our rotary club softball team... My wife had extra patches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sweet Mary Joseph... Welcome to Lucas! I'm the sheriff, Charley Baskins. I keep the peace here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't you just hiding in the kitchen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... A non-confrontation approach sometimes is the best method to keep aggression...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was hiding in the kitchen. Charley looks at them for a moment, then starts to tear up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an embarrassment. Charley hurries off to the bathroom. The guys look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLEY walks through the town square with DOUG, BOB, WOODY and DUDLEY. There's a stage and booths set up around the park in the center - ready for the block party. As the news spreads that the Wild Hogs are friendly, the townspeople start to take to the streets again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about all the confusion when you arrived. Those guys are pretty rough. You're the first people to ever stand up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Woody is the one who really--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey-- we should probably share the credit. I mean, I just basically kicked that guy's ass. Man! You know how good that felt!? Yeah! Bob punches a handicapped parking sign, which rattles against its post, then falls to the ground. Bob immediately looks regretful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice. Now the paraplegics can park down the block and get more exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly meek again) Should I fix it? Oh, man. I should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I didn't mean to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about it. We only have one cripple and he gets pulled around in a wagon. Come on, I want to show you guys something. Charley leads the guys off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley flips on the light in a neatly organized police garage. In the middle sits a sparkling, unridden Harley Davidson police bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. That's fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ride this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. The Hells Angels would take it to pieces if they ever saw me on it. I just keep it in here. Polish it and so forth. But I'd never let them see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those guys are that big of a problem, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They ride into town a few times a month and get drunk, damage property... Basically turn the place upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the police don't do anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, It's a small town - and me and the Dooble brothers are the only law. And they're still pretty green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you call a bigger town or something for backup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've done that a few times. But the gang is always gone by the time they get here. We've also tried wearing riot gear, which does protect you from being hit, but not from being dragged. Also, one of the Dooble brothers tried to throw tear gas, but the bottle exploded and blew off his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's hard to look at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, we want you guys to stay at our hotel tonight on us... Seeing as you're the new town heroes and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 65. The guys look flattered. Except Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks, but we're actually moving on--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd be honored to stay. Thank you. Woody's looks at Doug in protest. Doug gives him a stern glare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you're not in a rush to leave in the morning-- We've got a great trout stream you might want to check out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool! Let's fish! Doug shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Let's do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh. No, I'm putting my foot down, here. I still get a vote on what we do, you know? And I want my vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Of course you get a vote. Woody nods and looks at Bob and Dudley. They clearly intend to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I actually get three votes. Because I planned the trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you didn't plan the voting system. I did. So you only get one. Sorry. Doug, Bob and Dudley walk off. Woody fumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? Old Doug wasn't such a douchebag!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCK has arrived at the bar, which is just a burned shack at this point. The Hell's Angels are gathered around, watching JACK beat the crap out of a remaining wall with a pipe. He finally stops when the wall has crumbled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those assholes think they can cross the Hells Angels? Do you know how bad they've made us all look!? The gang nods. They all look pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those guys have some balls. Balls I will put in my mouth and chew on!! The gang looks at Jack with a slight smile. OILCAN chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to put balls in your mouth? The gang laughs. Jack realizes what the joke is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I'm not-- I'm going to put my foot up their asses! Both feet! Hell, I'm going to stick anything I can in their asses, and I'm going to enlov it. The guys start laughing again. Jack boils red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!! I didn't mean-- Just get on your damn bikes! We're riding to Lucas! The guys start towards their bikes. Oilcan sidles up next to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it helps if you say things in your mind first, then say it out loud, you know? Jack looks at Oilcan for a beat, then bends down, picks a dart up out of the ash, and jabs it into his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oww! Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did that in my mind, first. Jack smiles calmly and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB, WOODY and DUDLEY exit out of an old fashioned hotel next to the diner. They cross to the town square, where the block party is in full swing. Townspeople mingle around eating corn-on-the-cob and hotdogs. Up on the stage, a plump, middle-aged man with a goatee and a polo shirt tucked into dockers - sings Justin Timberlake's "Rock Your body."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you grab your girls, And you grab a couple more. And you all come meet me, in the middle of the floor. Gonna rock your body! 'Till the break of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man drops to his knees at the edge of stage and reaches his hand out to the audience, like the star of a boy band; However, it's clearly making the people on the dance floor uncomfortable. Meanwhile, Doug, Bob, Woody and Dudley walk through the square and are instantly greeted, patted on the back and thanked by each townsperson they pass. The word is out that these guys are heroes. Doug gives a "can you believe this?" look to the other guys - who are just as thrilled as him. They're eating it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people love us. This is nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They think we're bad asses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's not get too carried away with it. The truth is we're just regular guys. Let's not forget that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the best thing is to keep a low profile. Don't cause any waves. Then if somebody pushes us too far, Boom! We go Billy Jack upside their heads!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to go Billy Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooo. I'm just minding my own business. I don't want to cause any trouble. Dudley turns to Woody and stares at him. Woody looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's waiting for you to say something else, then he's going to kick you. Dudley gets a deflated look and backs off of Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug just saved you a world of hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid of your cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... He once bit me on the sack. Dudley walks off towards the beer tent. Woody looks to the other guys with a puzzled look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. He was unclogging his bathtub drain and the cat thought it was a ball of yarn. Doug and Woody wince. ANGLE ON: DUDLEY, at the beer tent. He gets in line, and realizes he's behind MAGGIE. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Dudley is wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... I, uh---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you call a Mercedes in Harlem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 69. Maggie looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing-- uh... Maggie notices the tattoo on Dudley's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. You like macs too, huh? I've got a vintage Apple 2e. Restored it from scratch. Dudley's jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-- have a cookie jar made out of a 2e. For fig newtons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. I like fig newtons. Dudley collects himself and tries to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They're like fried chicken at a-- No, that's not... Dammit! This is hard. Maggie smiles sweetly as Dudley fumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to dance? Dudley goes to respond, then decides to just give an emphatic nod. Maggie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB and WOODY are sitting at a picnic table, drinking beer out of plastic cups. They lean back and soak up the small town celebration around them. It's a great night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't get any better than this, huh? Bob notices Doug getting ready to chomp down on a piece of garlic bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot of carbs. Doug stops, mid-bite, and puts the bread down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Bob. You saved me from all that... buttery, garlicky flavor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No he didn't. Woody takes the garlic bread and crams it in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you choke on it. CHARLEY approaches with his two deputies, EARL DOOBLE and BUCK DOOBLE. They are chubby, thirty-year old twins - identical in every way, except for the fact that Buck is missing an ear on the right side of his head... which the skin has scarred back over. It doesn't look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy, guys! Welcome to the block party! These are my deputies: Earl and Buck Dooble. Earl shakes the guys hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Earl and he's Buck. Just remember, the brother with the word "ear," in his name, has both on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only say that because I'm on his right side. Which as you can see, is blown off. Earl laughs again, as BUCK extends his hand - oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Buck and this is Earl. Good luck telling us apart! Buck laughs and turns to Charley, exposing his missing ear to the guys. They draw back a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's nice to meet you guys. You've got a great town here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we got everything here. Good people, good fishing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do have convicted child molesters, though. We have to disclose that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if they don't have kids, Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to be safe, though. (yells at crowd of people) Hey!! Thomas Milborn! A bookish man with a tweed jacket turns around and looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convicted child molester. Thomas Milborn nods glumly and pulls his hands out of his pockets. The guys look at each other uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Still a nice town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're not a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Thomas Milborn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DUDLEY is on the dance floor with MAGGIE. The middle aged guy on stage is letting loose with a rendition of Usher's "Yeah." Maggie and Dudley dance conservatively for a moment, but as the beat gets ahold of Dudley, he starts getting into it. He starts spinning around at a rapid pace, then drops to his knees, slaps the ground and shakes his head to the music. Maggie watches curiously as Dudley pulls himself along the ground by his elbows - then springs up to his feet and starts a move that resembles a sprinkler. Maggie grins - actually amused by Dudley's rhythmic passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 72. ANGLE ON: The Wild Hog's table. The guys sit with Charley, Buck and Earl - watching Dudley with a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like your friend and Maggie are hitting it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think he really likes that girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Maggie's a great woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Big cans, too. Buck liked her, but you know... He's a deformed freak. Buck, on Earl's left, stares out at Maggie and Dudley, deaf to the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to like that girl... but then I realized, I can do better. The guys look at Buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, why are you guys taking this road trip, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, just to escape for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we're not escaping anything, man. We're on this trip to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. Sometimes things in life can bother you, and sometimes nothing in life can bother you. Either way, you've got take a break from it. Happiness is somewhere between boredom and stress. Doug is surprised at Charley's insight. So is Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Which is why we need to keep riding until we figure out where that happiness is. You don't get old Doug back by just staying put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Doug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Apparently I've lost him. I don't sing Bon Jovi anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did lose him, Doug. You know why? You're housebroken. You're too comfortable. You've got to snap out of it! Doug nods halfheartedly. He knows woody might be right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody's got a point, there. Comfortable can be a bad thing. You have to wake up and slap the bull once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! Slap the bull! (then, to Charley) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slapping the bull is kind of the local test of manhood. It's a way to prove you aren't controlled by fear. We've all done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Even torn-open head, here. He nods at Buck, on his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I slapped the bull once. Woody smiles slyly. Doug looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're slapping the bull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we need to. I mean, we can have our own test of manhood. Let's see how many ears of corn we can eat or something. I'll start. Doug grabs an ear of corn and takes a bite, but Woody just grins with that reckless look in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are slapping the bull. Doug knows it's no use. He nods, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB, WOODY, CHARLEY, BUCK and EARL approach a fence surrounding a pasture. Charley smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are. The Lucas test of manhood. Slap the bull. Charley gestures to a lone bull grazing in the pasture. He's a frighteningly large bull with enormous horns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. So it's literally slapping a bull?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Right on the ass. Then high-tail it out of there, because he can kill ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Um... Woody? This was your idea, so... go ahead. Woody nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'm going in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yeah. I'm gonna slap the shit out of that bull. Like, pimp-style. The guys look at him, surprised and somewhat impressed. Woody takes a breath and climbs over the fence. He approaches the Bull very quietly and cautiously. He gets within three feet of it, leans in and slaps the Bull hard on the ass. The bull makes an annoyed sound and turns around, but Woody is already hightailing it back to the fence, with an exhilarated look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whhhheeeeeeew! Woody gets to the fence and hurls himself over. The guys all applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Wow! That felt so good. I just slapped a big fat bull right on his ass! Did you hear how pissed he was!? I just pissed of a bull! (back to Bull) Bitch! Woody high fives all the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'm in. I'm slapping that bull. The guys cheer as Doug climbs over the fence and starts heading towards the Bull. The group all leans on the fence, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for bringing us out here. Doug really needs this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. This is good for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Glad we could help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and we've never seen it done twice in a row. It'll be interesting to see how the bull takes being slapped now that he's alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alert? Woody and Bob look at each other, then to the Bull - which Doug is about to slap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug, wait! It's too late. Doug slaps the bull hard, and turns to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeeeew!! Yeah! Doug runs across the field, but the Bull - now fully alert - swivels with magnificent agility and breaks into an angry charge towards Doug. The guys all watch in horror as the Bull quickly gains on Doug. Doug sees the fear on the guys faces and looks back over his shoulder. His smile quickly turns to terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhhhh! It's too late. The Bull catches Doug and bucks him into the air. Doug flies ten feet and comes crashing down on the muddy grass. The Bull takes a few steps back and starts lining up another charge at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no you don't! Woody jumps over the fence and runs into the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heeeeey! Hey you! Come get me, Bull! The Bull notices Woody and starts to Charge him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run, Doug! Go! Doug climbs to his feet and sees the bull charging Woody. Woody realizes he's in trouble and starts to run again. The bull quickly catches him and rams him into the air. Woody lands hard, with a grunt. The bull turns back to charge at Woody again, and Bob jumps over the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Leave him alone! You want some of this!? Come get this! Bob sprints out into the field. The bull snorts and starts towards him. The Bull closes on Bob quick, but at the last moment Bob dives of the way. The bull goes flying past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah! Missed me, you fat bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 77. Doug and Woody look impressed as Bob helps them hurry towards the fence. Charley and Buck hold a gate open for them as the Bull makes a turn and lines the group up, but they've already made it to the gate. They go through and Charley shuts it behind them. They lean back on the fence, trying to gather their bearings, except Bob - who is thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see me? I dodged him! I dodged that stupid cow! How cool am-- Suddenly, the Bull charges into the fence, which Bob's butt is sticking through. Bob goes flying and lands face down in the dirt. He scrambles back up, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch! You want to keep it going!? You want to take cheap shots!? Come on! Bob tries to climb back into the pasture, but the guys restrain him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me your gun! Give me the gun! He deserves it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill you! Doug and Woody hold on to Bob until he calms down. Doug and Woody start to laugh. Bob cools off for another moment, then starts laughing as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No this is living!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just slapped the bull! The group high fives each other in congratulations, and starts away: Bruised, muddy and laughing. ANGLE ON: THE BULL. He pushes on the gate that Charley was holding open. The gate swings open. ANGLE ON: WOODY, BOB and DOUG. They walk with Charley and the Dooble brothers, laughing and carrying on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 78. Bob does an impression of how he dodged it and goes for some more high fives - but suddenly, the bull charges into frame and nails him. As Bob goes flying; we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The block party is winding down. Dudley is sitting by himself at a picnic table, in post-Maggie bliss. DOUG, WOODY and BOB approach, dirty and beaten from the bull - but, carrying on happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, did you see the look on Bob's face when he got up? Didn't dodge him that time! Woody and Doug laugh. Bob looks pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to go back there with a rifle tomorrow and shoot one of his legs off. Then we'll see who's tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why just one leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I want to kick him in the face. Doug and Woody laugh again. Bob just steams. They spot DUDLEY, and head over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dud. You look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I danced with her. And she likes macs. You know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a soulmate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said the color ipod was your soulmate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was. But now, I realize that ipod was just a well-designed whore. The guys smile. It's been a good night for all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's go back to the hotel. We've got to get up early to do some fishing. The guys start walking towards the Main Street hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine. But after fishing - we hit the open road and keep moving, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open road, baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild Hogs ride! The guys continue with enthusiastic cheers as we hear the off-screen rumble of engines. Doug looks down the street and sees: THE HELLS ANGELS. All forty of them are riding into town - and the guys will be in their view any second. Woody is frozen with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Woody, you're going to have to talk to these guys again. Get them to leave this town alone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiiiiiiiidee! DOUG, BOB and DUDLEY look confused. Woody looks around desperately for somewhere to hide - but the Hells Angels are too close. There's no time. Woody spots a port-o- potty from the block party and starts corralling Doug, Bob and Dudley into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go! Go! Go! Woody pushes his puzzled friends into the port-o-potty, then gets in with them and shuts the door, just as the Hells Angels cruise by them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four guys are squished inside the port-o-potty like sardines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody!? What the hell is wrong with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh! They'll hear you! Don't make a sound!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hells Angels park their bikes. We see all the townspeople have stopped enjoying themselves, and just stand there, scared. Jack gets off his bike and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Lucas. Now, as hurt as I am that you're having a party and didn't invite us... We're only here for one reason. The "Wild Hogs." Where the hell are they!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug looks at Woody. He's starting to figure it out. Woody guiltily avoids Doug's glare and watches the Hells Angels through a vent in the port-o-potty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The townspeople aren't saying a word. Jack continues to pace in front of the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, now. You shouldn't be protecting them. These "Wild Hogs," not only passed us when we specifically told them not to, they drained out all our gas and burned down our bar. Like the little cowards they are. Now where are they!!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon hearing this, BOB, DUDLEY and DOUG all look at WOODY, who shrugs sheepishly. Bob is enraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch! Bob lunges at Woody, but the sudden shifting of weight is too much for the port-o-potty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The port-o-potty tips over. All the Hells Angels turn and look as it crashes over on it's side. They continue to stare at it curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys, now on their side, freeze as they see through the vent that the Hells Angels are staring at them. It's a very tense moment as they wait to see if they've been discovered. After a moment, we hear a "glup, glup, glup," And the guys smell something curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that blue port-o-potty juice. It's coming out of the can. The guys all cringe in disgust, but know they can't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack finally turns away from the pot-o-potty and smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that's a port-o-potty that ain't worth shit. The Hell's Angels all laugh and turn back to the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then. Nobody wants to tell me where they are? Fine. Maybe this'll jar your memory. Jack takes a garbage can and tosses it into the diner window. The crowd gasps, as the Hells Angels laugh. CHARLEY steps out of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're out at Mckinley's pasture. Something about slapping a bull. It's up past the lake a ways. Jack smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (to Hells Angels) Saddle up, boys. The guys get on their bikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if they ain't there. We'll be back reeeal soon. Because I don't let any man get away from me. The gang snickers. Jack realizes;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the hell up! I didn't-- You know what I meant! Jack starts his bike and roars out of the town. The others follow him, gunning their bikes and leaving skid marks and smoke in their trail. A kid yells at the Hells Angels as they ride out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead and come back! The Wild Hogs aren't afraid you! The Wild Hogs aren't afraid of anything! Suddenly, the door pops open on the port-o-potty and the WILD HOGS topple out of it in a heap. We see they're soaked in blue port-o-potty juice. They scramble to their feet and run towards the large fountain in the middle of the town square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 83.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG/BOB/WOODY/DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Ahhhh!/ I'm going to vomit!/ Ecchhh! The townspeople watch in silence as the guys jump into the fountain and try to rinse off. Bob puts his head under a water-spouting marble fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It got in my hair! Gross! The guys desperately try to rinse off the juice - then, drenched from head to toe, turn their glare to Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lied, didn't you!? You stood there and lied to us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did! You're a stinking liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it for you guys! I wanted you to live!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live!? We're going to die, Woody! You burned down their bar! We are dead men!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man. I thought it was going to happen slowly. I thought I had time! Dudley sits on the fountain edge and starts to tear up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? That's it!? You're sorry!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sorry! I just didn't want us to go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? It's just a stupid vacation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't have anything to go back to, okay! Doug and Bob go silent. Woody looks away - trying to collect himself. After a moment, he faces them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lost everything. The firm fired me, Claudia left me... It's all gone. My whole life is gone. I don't even have enough money to get my lawn raked anymore. Doug, Bob and Dudley are stupefied. Woody takes a deep breath and continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I couldn't go back. This isn't a vacation for me, it's the only thing I have left. There's nothing more in my life but you guys. So, I lied about the Hells Angels. I lied because I wanted to have one thing in my life that wasn't a complete failure. A real trip with my best friends... You're all I got. I'm sorry. Woody lowers his head. The guys take this in for a minute. Woody looks at them, waiting for their sympathy. Finally, Doug speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing, to Woody) This trip is just you running from your life. Your miserable, screwed up life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you knew you couldn't go back to it, so instead you screwed up our lives, too... You asshole! Woody's puppy-dog face dissolves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! I see how important I am to you guys. That's just fine. I just thought being a "Wild Hog" meant something! Woody takes off his "Wild Hogs" jacket and throws it at their feet. He hops out of the fountain and storms off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't mean anything! It's just a patch my wife made!! Doug, Bob and Dudley look at each other. After a moment, they look over to the sidewalk and see: ALL THE TOWNSPEOPLE, staring at them in disappointed silence. Slowly, the townspeople turn and quietly head back to their homes. Doug, Bob and Dudley lower their heads in disgrace. So much for being heroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG stands in the darkened police station with DUDLEY, CHARLEY, BUCK and EARL. CHARLEY looks out the window with DOUG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like they're winding down some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hells Angels have returned, and set up shop in the diner, but are also flowing out onto the street. Jack stumbles into the middle of the road, with a bottle of tequila in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Wild Hogs. We know you're in town somewhere, 'cause you haven't checked out of the hotel. We're a little smarter than you thought, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yeah we are!! Wheeew! Oilcan smashes a beer can against his own head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we're going to wait right here 'till you show up. Weeks, if we have to. Hell, we might just make ourselves the "Lucas Angels." That has a nice ring to it, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 86. Jack laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys watch the commotion through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap. I was thinking of that for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys just stay in the station tonight. No one needs to go out there and be a hero and end up getting hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Charley. Charley and the Dooble brothers look a little surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. So... You're not going out there? Doug sighs in irritation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're the cop. Why don't you go out there? Charley is visibly hurt. His lip starts to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not cool, man. Charley runs out the back door of the station. EARL shakes his head and looks at Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, people have feelings. Sure, I make comments about "chum face," here. But that's because every time I look at him I see parts of his brain. But nobody has the right to hurt Charley like that. He has both sides of his head. Earl storms off, leaving BUCK, who was standing on his left and hasn't heard or seen any of them leave. He stands there, looking at Doug and Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... They left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Buck turns and sees Earl and Charley have gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. Buck hurries out the door after Charley and Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug wakes up on a cot in an open jail cell. He walks out of the cell, and over to the window. ANGLE ON: The Main Street Diner: The Hells Angels bikes are still parked outside, and the bikers appear to be passed out in various booths, chairs, and the street out front. BACK ON: The police station. Dudley and Bob approach the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're still out there. Passed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I talked to Karen. She going to fly out here, rent a mini-van, and pick us up. We'll just ship the bikes back later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, we can't leave. They'll just stay here and keep terrorizing this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? They can call the National guard or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? To be stationed here permanently? Because these guys will just come back when they're gone. And it'll be even worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've created this problem, Bob. We've got to think of a way to solve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Karen is really insistent she come drive us back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her "no," Bob. Bob looks uncomfortable at this thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're going to have to, Bob! We're not going to screw over an entire town because you're afraid of women! Bob stands up, insulted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry I'm not brave like you, Doug! The guy who gets injections in his scalp so he won't go bald! Bob storms out the back door of the police station. Dudley looks to Doug, curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do? Doug shrugs weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you can storm out too, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I mean, I thought about going to see Maggie while those guys are asleep, but you need me right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man. Doug smiles and gives Dudley a squeeze on the shoulder. Dudley is clearly disappointed, having assumed Doug would tell him to go see Maggie. Dudley just stands there, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always asking me if I'm okay! Dudley quickly storms out of the police station. Doug nods to himself and slumps down on an office chair.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC CUE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUES THROUGH THE FOLLOWING SCENES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug exits and looks around the corner of the building, making sure the Hells Angels are still sleeping, then starts walking towards a wooded park behind the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug walks through the park, looking depressed. He passes through a small playground, and has a seat on a bench. He watches all the children play, and his eyes fall on four young boys happily riding their bicycles together. They have cards in their spokes, making engine sounds as they ride around having a great time together. Doug smiles and watches them play together.

dialogues.speaker: BUD, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Thought you might be out here. Doug turns and sees BUD, the owner of the diner, Bud has a seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bud. Look, I'm sorry we got your town in all this trouble. This trip was supposed to fix problems, not cause them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe it's trying to and you just won't let it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Bud smiles and looks out at the kids playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the funny thing about life. It has to be an adventure to feel right. But when you become a husband and a Dad, you realize adventure is risk, and a family man has no place in his life for risk. Doug takes this in, then realizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. That's why I stopped singing Bon Jovi. Life used to be a risk. That was old Doug. And now it's gone. I've taken away all the risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. And if you try to make livin' too safe, then it's not livin' at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not. And I have a will, now. So, I only have so much livin' left. And somehow I've lost the best part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe these will help you find it. Bud puts a styrofoam container on Doug's lap. Doug looks into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. To fish with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends that screw up. Angry bikers. That's not something you should be avoiding. That's something you need. Doug takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that have to do with worms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go down to the lake and find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 91. Bud smiles and walks off. Doug looks down at the worms, considering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug walks up to the shore and sees Woody, trying to push a canoe towards the water. Woody notices Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Going fishing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. Woody gets the canoe to the water and looks back at Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, in here. Doug holds up the styrofoam cup. Woody shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Let's go. Doug helps Woody shove the boat out into the water. They both hop in as it floats away from the shore. They sit there staring off in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Look, man. I'm sorry about Claudia. And the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, you shouldn't have lied to us--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I screwed up! It happens. Maybe from now on I'm better off just doing things on my own! Woody starts to get up, but then looks at the water around him, and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would have stormed off right then, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Doug nods and looks out at the water. They sit there in silence for another moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to lose, Doug. I've lost everything else and I didn't want to lose this trip with you guys. When we're together, it's like we're all college kids still. I'm not a guy with a broken marriage and failed career. I'm just with my best friends, being happy. And to keep it going, I forgot about what made it so great... That friends never let each other down. Until now. I screwed up the last thing I had left. You guys deserve better. I'm sorry-- Woody eyes water a little and he quickly turns away from Doug. They sit there for another moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what's the point of being in a motorcycle gang if we can't ourselves in a little trouble? Woody looks back at him. Doug smiles a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be okay, man. Woody smiles a little as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't kill us, right? Just a... really bad beating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We won't die. I don't think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. And how much could a punch really hurt? Not much, probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the good thing is we'll be able to know for sure. That'll be cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go find the Bob and Dudley. Doug looks around the canoe for a paddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring the paddles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I wasn't even going to take this thing out, but I didn't want you to think I was just standing at the lake waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud told me to stand at the lake and wait for you. Doug nods. Bob walks up on the shore, holding a styrofoam cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob. Worms? Bob looks at the styrofoam cup and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we all good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Bob. We're all good. Woody smiles at Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw us that paddle. Bob nods and picks up a paddle. He throws it toward the canoe, but it lands ten yards short and sinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 94. Bob grabs another paddle and throws it. This time it lands even shorter. Bob looks around for another paddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were those the only two paddles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Bob sits down on the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys'll drift in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Woody and Doug look around at the water. It's as still as glass. They sit there awkwardly as Bob waits on shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cook from the diner is at the kitchen stove, making something in a big pot, as a crowd of townspeople eat in the kitchen and dining room. MAGGIE and DUDLEY cross through the kitchen, and out to the front porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie sits on the porch swing and takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we can't seat many people in there, but at least we're back in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry those jerks are in your diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, we're used to them costing us money. Last year we spent more on window glass than pancake batter. All because of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me sick. Thinking they're too good for pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I meant... They damage the diner a lot. They damage the whole town. I'm just sorry you guys got dragged into it. You were just out to have a good vacation. Dudley looks at Maggie sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has been the best vacation of my life. I met you. Maggie blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bikers probably tell all the girls that. This hits Dudley. He suddenly looks troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie, I have to tell you something. I'm not really a cool biker or a cool... anything. I'm a computer programmer. A nerd. My cat doesn't even like me. She watches me sleep and I don't know why. I think she's waiting for me to stop breathing. I'm just a... Geek. I'm sorry if you thought I was somebody I'm not. Maggie takes this in. After a moment, she smiles and kisses Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a geek, Dudley. You're sweet and your honest and... You're the coolest guy I know. Your cat is crazy if it doesn't like you as much as I do. Dudley smiles. He has completely fallen for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I better get back inside. I've got to set some chairs up in the family room for the lunch rush. People gotta eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 96. Maggie smiles and heads inside. Dudley watches her go, then grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, people will eat. Don't you worry, Maggie. People will eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DUDLEY kicks open the front door. JACK and the other Hells Angels are inside, drinking and carrying on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, let's end this! The Hells Angels don't even notice him. Dudley bites his lip in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! ! Dudley takes a table full of empty beer glasses and flips it over. Everyone in the diner goes silent and looks at him. Jack stands up and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well. One of you came to face the music, huh? That's brave. And stupid. The Hells Angels laugh. Dudley takes a deep breath and walks up to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here to face any music. I'm here to make you a deal. A deal I think you'd be smart to take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave the town of Lucas, and my friends alone, and I do something for you. Something you can't live without. Jack looks interested. Dudley confidently sets a laptop on the counter, and punches a few keys. He swivels it around to show the gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See where that says "Domain for sale?" Guess what that means. Your gang doesn't have a website! Nothing! No way to tell people about your history, post photos, sell shirts... You guys are living in the complete dark ages! (laughs cockily, then) So they way I see it: I need a favor from you and you need a favor from me. Jack walks over to the computer and looks at Dudley for a moment. He then picks the computer up and smashes it down on the ground. It breaks into a hundred pieces. Jack smiles at Dudley and puts his foot through what's left of it. The Hells Angels stifle laughter. Dudley is starting to look a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No deal. Dudley nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then. Thanks for hearing me out. Dudley starts for the door, but several Hells Angels move over and block his path. Dudley stops and collects himself for a moment - then breaks into a panicked sprint for the other exit. The Hells Angels quickly spring into action and tackle him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanctuary! Sanctuary!! The Hells Angels pull off him, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanctuary. You have to take me to a church and leave me alone. The Hells Angels look at each other and shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. The Hells Angels move back in on him. Dudley closes his eyes and rolls into a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB, and WOODY are walking back from the lake, and pass by Maggie's house. BUD, standing on the porch, sees them and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're heading back to town, I wouldn't go on an empty stomach. The guys see Bud and smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come have lunch. This is kind of our "fallout" diner. Smaller kitchen, but less piss on the bathroom floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we can change that. Bud laughs as the guys enter the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB and WOODY are sitting at one of many card tables arranged in the family room, eating lunch. CHARLEY enters through the front door..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys. Having your final meal? Charley laughs. Doug, Bob and Woody don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are Buck and Earl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're coming. Buck's ear is giving him some equilibrium problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 99. EARL ENTERS, holding the door open for BUCK, who walks through slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep your eyes forward and head up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Buck walks a few more steps, then starts to tilt left. He quickly loses his balance and falls sideways, taking out a card table full of food and the old man sitting at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit. Earl helps Buck up and they join the guys at their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys. Having your final meal? Buck and Earl laugh. Nobody else does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly, to Buck and Earl) That's out of line, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Buck looks around the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, isn't one of you missing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dudley's with Maggie somewhere. MAGGIE COMES OUT OF THE KITCHEN and approaches the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys. Where's Dudley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's with you, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I thought he went to find you guys. Doug shares a worried glance with Bob and Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley, can I borrow your phone? Charley hands it to him, and Doug starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley has mine. I'll just call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a phone? What happened to freedom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needed to call his answering machine so his cat could hear his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go. It's ringing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably snuck off somewhere to buy you some romantic gift or something. No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. He's never had a girlfriend so he's probably getting carried away. He once drank eighteen Mocha Latte's because the Starbucks clerk was smiling at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember that. His pee turned brown and he started crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And the girl wasn't even smiling - she just had a cleft lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Dudley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands next to Dudley, who is duct-taped to a chair with so much tape that it looks like he's in a cocoon. Only his head is uncovered. Jack holds Dudley's cellphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowingly, to group) Nope. The Hells Angels have him. Doug gives a look to the other guys. They mouth "Shit:"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right, the Hells Angels. Your friend paid us a little visit. And now he's hurting reeeeal bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I actually feel pretty-- Jack kicks Dudley's chair with his foot. It tips over and lands on it's side - with Dudley in it. Dudley looks out at the floor, helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, a peanut. Dudley tries to stick his tongue out to get the peanut. Jack notices and kicks it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So here's what we're going to do, now. You guys are going to pay us a visit. And you're going to bring a "disobedience fee," of ten thousand dollars. Cash. And don't even think about calling any cops. Just you guys and ten grand. And if you don't show up in an hour - Well then, We'll just take the fine out of your friend's legs... Which we're going to break with a tire iron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to phone) Don't bring the money, guys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a computer programmer! I don't need my legs! Jack considers this and turns back to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hands! We'll break his hands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit. (yelling to phone) Bring the money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug shakes his head at Dudley's stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll bring the money. Just don't touch our friend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I won't touch him if you bring that money. But if you don't, I'll be touching him all night long. And I'll be enjoying it. The other bikers suddenly stifle laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!? There was nothing wrong with that one! That was tough! Those guys are afraid of me, now. They know how much I want 'em! The gang laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!! The gang stops laughing, off Jack's warning glare. Dudley looks up from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey can we call my cat, now? She needs to hear my voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 103. Jack looks down at Dudley, then to the other bikers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me more duct tape? A biker nods and grabs another role of duct tape. He heads over to Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG sits in a chair, deep in thought. BOB, WOODY, EARL, BUCK, and BUD stand with other members of the town. MAGGIE is on a couch, sobbing into her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Dudley. He went there to save everybody and now they're going to break his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No they aren't. We're going to get him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sure are. I'm going to call the Highway Patrol. They'll be there in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. They said no law. We can't risk them doing anything to Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's right. We can call the Highway Patrol after we get Dud back, but we shouldn't piss these guys off while he's still in their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to call Karen and have the cash wired out of our savings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No way. This is my fault. All this is my fault. I have some money in my severance package. We're using it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, he did this because of me. I have a thousand dollars in tip money I want to put in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a couple thousand in the diner emergency fund I'll put in, too. Doug, who has been thinking all this over, stands up from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nobody is paying anything. Everyone stops and gives Doug a puzzled look. He has a new fire behind his eyes. His suburban quietude has transformed into something more... valiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not calling the Highway patrol. We're not gathering ten thousand dollars. We're going over there and getting our friend back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's the safest plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not. But sometimes you have to do the things that aren't safe, to create a world that you're happy being in. These Hells Angels don't want our ten thousand dollars. They want our dignity. They want us to be afraid of them just like this town is. And once they know we're afraid, they can do whatever they want. That's how these guys exist. That's how they ride into this town and tear it to pieces... Because people want to keep their lives safe so badly, they give up the best part about it... Doug takes his Wild Hogs jacket and pulls it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .The adventure. Doug looks at Woody and Bob. Woody smiles and pulls on his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the friends. Woody steps over to Doug. Bob looks at them for a moment, then finally smiles and pulls on his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go slap the bull. Doug smiles and taps fists with Bob and Woody.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC CUE
dialogues.text: DOUG, BOB and WOODY walk along main street, shoulder to shoulder. They look to each other with a smile. Even though they're walking into the mouth of the beast, they're finally who they were in college again. Fearless. They approach the diner and stand out on the street, like gunslingers in the Old West, calling their enemy out of the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC CUE
dialogues.text: The front door of the bar opens and the HELLS ANGELS swagger out. After a moment, the gang parts and JACK steps out in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well. The "Wild Hogs." I'm glad to see you're finally showing us a little respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Dudley? Jack turns back and nods at one of the Hells Angels. They push DUDLEY forward. We see he is now completely cocooned in duct-tape - like a mummy. There is only a small slit for his mouth and eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled from tape) Hey, guyth. Doug shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hold tight, Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 106. Dudley tries to nod, but can't. He leans his torso back and forth to signal "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Hand him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Where's the cash? Doug looks to Bob and Woody. They nod encouragingly. Doug gathers his courage and turns back to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not giving you any money. Jack looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to play your games. We're all adults, here. It's not highschool. I'm sorry your bar got burned down, and we'll be glad to help you get it rebuilt, but we're done being bullied by you. Now give us back Dudley, and get out of this town. The Hells Angels start to laugh. Jack turns back to them and smiles, "Can you believe these guys?" Doug is starting to lose his cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells to Jack) Give us back our friend, asshole! The Hells Angels are suddenly silent. Jack turns back and looks at Doug in disbelief - then rage. Doug starts to look a little worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you just call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing some confidence) Ass... hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I was just going to pulverize your friend, here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now I'm pissed off. You're all going to get hurt. Hells Angels style. Guys! The Hells Angles nod and pick up various weapons: Crowbars, tire irons, bats... They start moving towards Doug, Woody and Bob. Bob looks to Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!? I thought they'd back down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can still outrun them. They're fat. Woody turns around to see Hells Angles have now closed in behind them, blocking their escape. Jack smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear that, guys!? He called you all fat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shit. (to Hells Angels) I meant full-figured. The Hells Angels close to within a few feet of the "Wild Hogs," and raise their weapons to strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!! Wait a minute! The Hells Angels stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to beat the shit out of us? Fine. But you outnumber us forty to three. You think there's honor in that? Why don't we make it fair, if you guys are so freaking tough? The leader of our gang against the leader of yours. Jack smirks. He's twice as big as Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me against you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But not just for Dudley. If you win, we'll give you ten grand and go back home. You'll never see us again. But... If I win, you let Dudley go and you never set foot in Lucas again. This town is off limits to the Hells Angels. Forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wild Hogs" writers first draft 7/06/05 108. Jack looks back to the Hells Angels, who chuckle. This will be a quick fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
